reviewText:
Introduction
Rewind is an attention grabbing modern puzzler. Every single puzzle is solved using the “Rewind” ability. This basically means first doing the actions which you need to perform in order to progress then resetting the level and replaying it with the help of a clone. The Rewind clone of yourself will repeat the actions you recorded while your current self can perform other actions. That’s the basics of gameplay. As you make your way through the levels, the difficulty increases with a suitable curve.

Gameplay
You awaken to find yourself alone in a strange area with no idea how you got there. You simply have a lingering memory that you were hungry, cold and tired before waking up in this laboratory-like setting. You wander aimlessly through the corridors in an attempt to find your way out. Suddenly you are greeted by a disembodied voice, which actually sounds surprised to see you running around inside those chambers. Fortunately, it is a friendly voice that tries to help you make it to the exit at the top of the tower. You are introduced to the “Rewind” system that lets you record actions that replay to assist you reach the exit of the chamber. Originally, you start with the ability to make one clone of yourself, and any mistakes you make in recording typically wipes out all progress for the level. Eventually you upgrade to having an additional clone and later still you gain the ability to selectively wipe the clone recordings. To help correct minor errors you are able to rewind the current recording back to a point before you made the error provided you have not finalized the recording, otherwise, you have to re-record all the actions again for that particular clone.

The gameplay itself involves elements you typically find in a Puzzler of this nature. Buttons to press and floor tiles to hold down. The recordings add a bit of timer element to the game as well as increase the challenge. You need to figure out what you need to do and when you need it done so that it syncs up with your next clones actions. You must try to time and predict how long you need to hold the current tile down before moving on to the next one. Failure to time it properly will cause the recorded clone to fall off the current track and no longer be able to complete its task or else it will cause it to premature press or release the tiles it controls. To further hamper your success, some levels also include enemy soldiers who want to shoot you with their laser pistols. Luckily, unlike in other Puzzler games such as Portal, you will find a laser gun of your own to shoot them right back. No need to worry about lining up pesky portals to deal with the enemy, you can just blast them yourself… or have one of your clones do it! Another element that is unique is that even though games like The Talos Principle have their own recorded clone to assist you with some levels, Rewind lets you either shoot those clones to make them stop doing what they are doing or shoot them just for fun! Also, you can strap an explosive backpack on a clone and send it to blow up a pesky grid blocking your way. I can tell you, playing Rewind is quite a blast.

The game consists of seven levels, each level consisting of seven stages. The difficulty increases slowly enough so those new to Puzzler games will be able to work their way through it without issue yet fast enough that veteran Puzzlers, like myself, will not get bored as the game catches up to “our speed.” The last stage of the last level has two solutions, the rest of the levels only have a singular solution. That is really one of my only complaints for the game and it is a minor one. To help make up for that small shortcoming the game also offers Time Trials and Clone Trials after you complete the stage. Time Trials force you to solve the level as fast as you can in order to beat the current record time. Clone Trials are similar except it limits you to the number of clones you are allowed to use to solve the level. Both of these help pad out your play time for this title which is a good thing as I found the game to be rather short having beaten the main levels in a little under three hours. Now I don’t really believe that this is the norm or the fault of the game itself. It is quite likely that it’s the fact that I have played so many Puzzlers that the solutions just popped out for me each time.

The dialogue between the female protagonist and the disembodied male voice flow together well. They add a lot of enjoyment to the game. Although the story seems a little disconnected from the game itself it was still well worth including! I won’t spoil what the story is about, but basically it involves a lot of paperwork being done. As a person who deals with a lot of paperwork, I found those jokes to be quite amusing.

Overall, if you are Puzzler fan like myself, you would be doing yourself a disservice by not giving Rewind a try. It fits well in the Genre and isn’t just a clone of other Puzzlers despite using similar mechanics.

Pros:Rewind’s Clone mechanics made solving puzzles quite enjoyable as it made you really think about what you needed to happen
Nice visuals and sounds
Enjoyable voiced story with pleasant, clear spoken voices
Despite relying on a single primary mechanic, the games levels do not feel repetitive
Time Trials and Clone Trials to extend gameplay

Cons:
Short: I beat the game in less than three hours. It could just be that I am too darn clever due to playing so many other Puzzlers that Rewind wasn’t able to stump me enough to slow me down

reviewText: I was always a pretty practical kid. When asked what my ideal superpower would be if I had one, my mind would always instantly think of either clones or the ability to control time. Well, what might happen if you could combine both of those powers? A little puzzle game called Rewind I suppose.\n\nThe BreakdownAntichamber. The Ball. Colortone. What do these games all have in common? Well, they're a helluva' lot like a little obscure game called Portal. We've all probably heard of it by now. If you somehow haven't though, it's a first-person puzzle platformer from almost a decade ago (wow, it's weird to think that!). It came out at a perfect time, when pretty much nothing like it was on the market, besides similar mods for other games. Well, flash forward nearly a decade later and it seems like the Portal-esque genre of first-person puzzlers is starting to become more and more saturated. FPPs (I'm lazy so that's what I'll call them) come out all the time
date: so what makes this one unique?\n\nWell
recommended: it's fresh and brings some interesting ideas to the table. See
hoursPlayed: Rewind works off of the notion that it's a co-op game that you play by yourself. The game gives you the tools to solve multi-player puzzles in the form of 2 extra clones and the ability to manipulate time. You can't fast forward at all
voteText: but you certainly are able to "rewind" to correct mistakes or move back to the start so you can use a different clone - hence

reviewText:
A First Person Time Travel Puzzle Game!

Puzzle design:
Pretty decent actually. Not amazing, but way better than a lot of other puzzle games I played. Most of the levels are fairly straight-forward, but some will make you stop and think and make you feel like you accomplished something after completing them. There are almost no annyoing levels (do this simple trick 10 times!" "backtrack the same path back and forth multiple times!") and most levels are short and can be solved in less then a minute if you know the solution already. The tutorial levels are probably the weakest one in the game since they are super hand-holdy (the game actually walks you through the first few levels step-by-step).

Mechanics:
The time-travel mechanics work fairly well. The animations could be sped up a bit and unfortunately sometimes your clones get out of sync when you rewind time (which is a freaking shame in a time-travel puzzle game). You can avoid those problems by playing carefully and not rushing every move you do
date:
so it is not game breaking.
A lot of levels also include a gun (and enemys to shoot). This is not a shooter though. The gun and the enemys just server as an additional puzzle mechanic and it works quite well for that.

Audio/Video/Performance:
The game is certainly not a high-quality-big-budget product. The graphics are servable and the voice acting is not annoying
recommended:
so it does not hamper the puzzle experience. The game runs very well and should be fine on lower-spec machines as well.

Story:
The story seems interesting but is kind of disconnected from the gameplay. It's a dialoge between the protagonist and another character. However they mostly talk about how you got here and now what you are doing here. This results in a situation where you could just listen to the story without even playing the game and it would make totally sense.

Commented gameplay by me:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VZB0FfWE1tA"

reviewText: I've been waiting for this game for a very long time. It's finally done, and it's very good. It's a pure puzzler about rewinding time and cooperating with recorded versions of your past self, which is a mechanic that's been explored before but never in quite this much detail. It's shorter than I'd like, but it's not too short (4 hours for me, which I think is probably pretty fast because I already knew how to do a lot of stuff.) It's pretty hard. I haven't done the time trials yet, but I might. They look interesting.\n\nA word of warning, however: the puzzle solutions in this game require precise execution. I like that, but if you're someone who gets frustrated if you know how to do a puzzle but can't quite get it to work, you're likely to have a bad time.

reviewText:
This game is really fun to play and is based on solving puzzles by making clones of yourself.  It has a nice soundtrack, suitably eerie music for its setting and engaging visuals (honestly, I kept jumping along the edges to see more of the world!).  The puzzles increase in complexity and the main gameplay style switches half way through to add another layer to the puzzles.

The storyline begins with you waking up in a lab with no knowledge of how you got there.  A disembodied voice provides some guidance as you make your way through the facility and dialogue between the two characters helps piece fragmented memories together to explain how you came to be where you are.

There are two outcomes - be sure to find them both!

reviewText:
Mind bending puzzle game using clones to solve stages. It's a lot of fun.

The soundtrack is good, optimization is fairly good. The main gripe i have would be the frame drops when pulling up your arms to summon clones(assuming it has to do with rendering the different scenes), luckily it doesnt effect gameplay since it happens prior to the action beginning.

All in all, it's a very unique game that's very fun. I would highly recomended if you enjoy puzzle games!

reviewText: The whole rewind time and play with your clones is a concept I've seen before though mostly on flash games.  This is an ok take on it but doesn't feel like a well playtested game.  The puzzles get repetitive and the story segments aren't very interesting.  I think it would be better with a more humorous tone like portal rather than taking itself so seriously.  Graphics are pretty good for a puzzle game but it failed to really grab me.  I might give it another shot if I'm bored.  Not quite good enough to recommend.  Too bad there's no meh" button."
